item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: Reflections on Programming
item.description:
Reflections on Programming

My perspective on programming has changed quite a bit over the years. Even in the few years since I started this blog I've noticed that I look at programming differently than I used to. If there's anything people who work with technology need to get used to, it's change, and I expect that my perspective will continue to evolve in the years to come.

item.title: Extracting image metadata at scale
item.description:
Extracting image metadata at scale

We have a collection of nearly two million images that play very prominent roles in helping members pick what to watch. This blog describes how we use computer vision algorithms to address the challenges of focal point, text placement and image clustering at a large scale.

item.title: Decentralized Autonomous Organizations: Ethereum Sparks Up Googles of Tomorrow
item.description:
Decentralized Autonomous Organizations: Ethereum Sparks Up Googles of Tomorrow

The recent rise of Ethereum has brought a wave of new users and enthusiasm into its possible applications. While smart contracts and their benefits are nothing new to the community one of the more disruptive use cases, DAOs have not been explored to the extent they deserve.

item.title: Can we save the open web?
item.description:
Can we save the open web?

The web felt very different fifteen years ago, when I founded Drupal. Just 7 percent of the population had internet access, there were only around 20 million websites, and Google was a small, private company. Facebook, Twitter, and other household tech names were years away from being founded.

item.title: Straight back down to Earth: A history of the Vertical Takeoff/Vertical Landing Rocket
item.description:
Straight back down to Earth: A history of the Vertical Takeoff/Vertical Landing Rocket

The recent rise of commercial rocketry funded by mega-rich technology entrepreneurs holds the promise of finally reducing the cost of placing payloads into orbit, partly through the generation of greater competition in the marketplace and application of more agile business models and project management, but also because we have seen the timely reemergence of...

item.title: Markov Chains explained visually
item.description:
Markov Chains explained visually

Explained Visually By Victor Powell with text by Lewis Lehe Markov chains, named after Andrey Markov, are mathematical systems that hop from one "state" (a situation or set of values) to another.

item.title: No title
item.description: That dystopian cyberpunk future where the richest company in the world fights the government over encrypted pocket computers

item.title: Ethereum Blockchain Project Launches First Production Release
item.description:
Ethereum Blockchain Project Launches First Production Release

Next-generation blockchain platform Ethereum has released 'Homestead' the first production release of its software, which was implemented at block 1,150,000 today. The introduction follows Frontier, Ethereum's inaugural release, which was released to developers in July 2015.

item.title: Hype springs eternal
item.description:
Hype springs eternal

Normally, it is Simon Taylor's job to persuade sceptical colleagues at Barclays that rapid technological change will disrupt the bank's business. So it comes as something of a surprise to have to dampen the excitement about the blockchain. "It's quite silly. I get ten invitations to speak at a conference every day," he says.
